edu.missouri.bayesianConstructor

Class Main

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.missouri.bayesianConstructor.Main

  • public class Main
extends java.lang.Object
    Provides a sample program that creates a Bayesian Network from economic data and stores it in an XML BIF file. The sample file can be found in the root folder. The functions contained herein are subject to be moved to other classes.
    Since:
    bayesianConstructor version 0.03 2016-03-18
    Version:
    0.09 2016-04-08
    Author:
    Fernando J. Torre-Mora

      Deprecated. 
      since version 0.05 (2016-03-20). A graph of nodes serves no other purpose than to create a edu.ucla.belief.BeliefNetwork; however, the graphs returned by this function are not fully supported by BeliefNetwork (Edges do not get updated properly). Use {@link #graphToNetwork(DirectedGraph, String[]) for this purpose instead.

    • Method Detail

      • dependency

        public static double dependency(java.util.List<java.lang.Double> X,
                                java.util.List<java.lang.Double> Y)
                         throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Computes the dependency between the two given lists of data. The dependency is defined as 1−STE(X→Y)/Y̅, where STE is the standard error of the predicted y-value for each x in a linear regression as defined by Microsoft: √((∑(Y−Y̅) − (∑(X&minus ;X̅)(Y−Y̅))² / ∑((X−X̅)²)) / (n-2)) STE returns values in the (0, Y̅) interval where Y̅ is the arithmetic sample means of Y. If a value is null; it, and the corresponding value in the other list, are ignored.
        Parameters:
        X - The list of values for the variable thought to be independent
        Y - The list of values for the variable thought to be independent
        Returns:
        the dependency score, a number between 0 and Y̅
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Since:
        0.01 2016-03-15

      • getDependency

        public static java.lang.Double[][] getDependency(java.util.List<java.util.List<java.lang.Double>> independent,
                                                 java.util.List<java.util.List<java.lang.Double>> dependent,
                                                 double minimum)
        Compute the degree to which dependent depends on independent by subtracting the forward dependency minus the negative dependency. The forward dependency is defined as 1−STE(X→Y)/Y̅ while the backward dependency is defined as 1−STE(Y→X)/X̅ where X is the independent data and Y is the dependent variable. The result should be between -1 and 1 unless the values are less than the minimum.

        Only the values whose forward dependency is greater than the minimum are kept. If a forward dependency comes out less than the minimum, it is returned as Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY. If these values are desired, minimum can be safely set to 0.

        Since:
        0.01 2016-03-15

      • getDependency

        public static java.lang.Double[][] getDependency(java.util.List<java.util.List<java.lang.Double>> independent,
                                                 java.util.List<java.util.List<java.lang.Double>> dependent)
        Compute the degree to which dependent depends on independent by subtracting the forward dependency minus the negative dependency. The forward dependency is defined as 1−STE(X→Y)/Y̅ while the backward dependency is defined as 1−STE(Y→X)/X̅ where X is the independent data and Y is the dependent variable. The result should be between -1 and 1 unless the values are less than the 0.5.

        Only the values whose forward dependency is greater than 0.5 are kept. If a forward dependency comes out less than 0.5, it is returned as Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY. If these values are desired, use getDependency(independent, dependent, 0)

        Since:
        0.01 2016-03-15

      • graphToNodeGraph

        @Deprecated
public static edu.ucla.structure.DirectedGraph graphToNodeGraph(edu.ucla.structure.DirectedGraph g,
                                                                             java.lang.String[] values)
        Deprecated. since version 0.05 (2016-03-20). A graph of nodes serves no other purpose than to create a edu.ucla.belief.BeliefNetwork; however, the graphs returned by this function are not fully supported by BeliefNetwork (Edges do not get updated properly). Use {@link #graphToNetwork(DirectedGraph, String[]) for this purpose instead.
        Wraps the name of each vertex in g in a edu.ucla.belief.StandardNode containing the specified values as the variables possible finite values.
        Parameters:
        g - the graph to be converted. Vertices must be Strings
        values - list of values for the new variables
        Returns:
        a graph g' were every vertex v now contains StandardNode(v,values)
        Throws:
        java.lang.ClassCastException - if the vertices in g are not Strings
        Since:
        0.03 2016-03-15

      • graphToNetwork

        public static edu.ucla.belief.BeliefNetwork graphToNetwork(edu.ucla.structure.DirectedGraph g,
                                                           java.lang.String[] values,
                                                           java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.util.List<java.lang.String>> structure,
                                                           char config,
                                                           double angle)
        Converts the given graph g into a BeliefNetwork. The function iterates through all the elements in the graph linearly and creates a BeliefNetwork copy as it goes. All nodes in the new Belief Network are given the same set of possible values: those in the values parameter. For this reason a universal set of names for discretized parameters is encouraged (such as "high", and "low")
        Parameters:
        g - The graph to base the new BeliefNetwork on. Vertices must be Strings
        values - The possible values for all nodes
        structure - A map showing what nodes should be grouped together when plotted. (Each key is a component identifier and each list is the nodes in that component. DomainKnowledge.layerMap() can be used).
        config - How to dispose the nodes on the canvas. Must be one of the NodePlacer valid configurations
        angle - What angle to use for the placement (see NodePlacer)
        Returns:
        a BeliefNetwork with one node and edge for every node and edge in the given graph g
        Since:
        0.09 2016-04-08

      • graphToNetwork

        public static edu.ucla.belief.BeliefNetwork graphToNetwork(edu.ucla.structure.DirectedGraph g,
                                                           java.lang.String[] values,
                                                           java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.util.List<java.lang.String>> structure)
        Converts the given graph g into a BeliefNetwork displaced using a NodePlacer.LAYERED configuration. All nodes in the new Belief Network are given the same set of possible values: those in the values parameter. For this reason a universal set of names for discretized parameters is encouraged (such as "high", and "low")

        This function is shorthand for graphToNetwork( g, values, structure, NodePlacer.LAYERED, Math.PI ) as of version 0.05

        Parameters:
        g - The graph to base the new BeliefNetwork on. Vertices must be Strings
        values - The possible values for all nodes
        structure - A map showing what nodes should be grouped together when plotted. (Each key is a component identifier and each list is the nodes in that component DomainKnowledge.layerMap() can be used).
        Returns:
        a BeliefNetwork with one node and edge for every node and edge in the given graph g
        Since:
        0.05 2016-03-20

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
                 throws java.lang.Exception
        Sample main program. The program receives a CSV file where the first row is assumed to be the column names, and in every other row, the first column is assumed to be a filtering criterion. Which filter criterion to use can be specified by using the third argument. The program looks for exact (case sensitive) string matching. Filtering is optional.

        The program assumes all useful data to be real numbers. Anything that cannot be cast to a real number is represented as null. For this reason, the names of columns that do not contain real numbers should not be included in the domain model.

        The program generates a Bayesian network with the data and stores it in XML-BIF format. The resulting file has the filename given in the second argument.

        Parameters:
        args - An array of length 2 or 3, where the first position contains the name of the file containing the input data, the second position contains the name of the file to write to, and the third position (in the case of length 3) contains a filtering criterion.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
